name: Moving Companies
metaTemplate: Local moving companies for {area}... get quotes, tips, and a quick checklist.
checklist: Confirm your building move window and elevator reservation
Ask for COI requirements and send them early
List large items (sofa, bed, appliances)
Clarify pricing: binding vs hourly, minimum hours, add-ons

faqs.q: How much do movers cost in {area}?
faqs.a: Costs depend on apartment size, stairs/elevator access, distance, and packing. Get 2–3 itemized quotes and compare add-ons.
Many co-ops/condos and doorman buildings require a Certificate of Insurance. Ask management for the exact wording.
End-of-month and summer book fast. If you can, choose mid-month weekdays for better availability and pricing.

name: Move-Out Cleaning
metaTemplate: Local move-out cleaning for {area}... get quotes, tips, and a quick checklist.
checklist: Confirm what your lease/building expects at move-out
Photograph condition before and after cleaning
Prioritize kitchen grease, oven, and bathroom grout
Ask if supplies and vacuum are included

faqs.a: Usually a deep clean of kitchen, bathroom, floors, baseboards, and surfaces. Confirm oven/fridge and inside cabinets.
Studios often take a few hours; larger apartments can take most of a day depending on condition.

faqs.q: Do I need to be there?
faqs.a: Not always—many cleaners can coordinate key pickup with doormen/lockboxes. Clarify access and instructions.

name: Storage Units
metaTemplate: Local storage units for {area}... get quotes, tips, and a quick checklist.
checklist: Estimate how many boxes/furniture pieces you need to store
Decide if climate control matters (art, electronics, clothing)
Check access hours and elevator/cart availability
Ask about promos vs long-term rates

faqs.a: If you’re storing electronics, artwork, musical instruments, or fabrics, climate control can help prevent damage.

faqs.q: Can storage be picked up from my apartment?
faqs.a: Some services offer valet pickup/dropoff. Traditional units require you to transport items to the facility.

faqs.q: What size unit do I need?
faqs.a: A studio often fits in a small unit; 1–2BRs usually need medium. Inventory your big items for accuracy.

name: Junk Removal & Donation Pickup
metaTemplate: Local junk removal & donation pickup for {area}... get quotes, tips, and a quick checklist.
checklist: Confirm what your building allows (service elevator, hours)
Separate donation-worthy items from trash
Ask about disposal fees for mattresses/appliances
Take photos so you get an accurate quote

faqs.a: Most crews take furniture, boxes, and appliances. Some items (paint, chemicals) may require special handling.
Many providers can arrange donation drop-offs. Ask for donation receipts if you need them.
Often by volume (truck space) plus labor. Stairs, long carries, and heavy items can increase cost.

name: Pest Control
metaTemplate: Local pest control for {area}... get quotes, tips, and a quick checklist.
checklist: Ask about integrated pest management (IPM)
Request a clear plan: treatment + follow-up
Seal obvious gaps and reduce food/water sources
Document issues (photos, dates) for management

faqs.a: Some issues improve in days; others need follow-ups. The key is combining treatment with sealing/cleaning.
Many providers have pet-safe protocols, but you should disclose pets and follow prep instructions closely.
In many cases, building-wide infestations are a landlord responsibility. Keep records and ask in writing.

name: Bed Bug Exterminators
metaTemplate: Local bed bug exterminators for {area}... get quotes, tips, and a quick checklist.
checklist: Confirm whether inspection is included
Ask which treatment method is recommended and why
Follow prep instructions exactly (laundry, bagging)
Request follow-up and re-inspection plan

faqs.q: How do I confirm it’s bed bugs?
faqs.a: Look for bites patterns, dark specks on seams, and live bugs. A professional inspection is the most reliable.
It depends on severity and building context. Heat can be fast; chemical programs can be effective with follow-ups.

faqs.q: How do I prevent bringing them to a new place?
faqs.a: Bag and launder textiles, inspect furniture, and avoid moving untreated items. Ask your provider for a move plan.

name: Rodent Control & Proofing
metaTemplate: Local rodent control & proofing for {area}... get quotes, tips, and a quick checklist.
checklist: Ask for an inspection to find entry points
Prioritize sealing over repeated baiting alone
Improve trash storage and reduce clutter
Schedule follow-up to confirm activity stops

faqs.q: Why do mice keep coming back?
faqs.a: Without sealing entry points, new rodents can enter. Proofing plus sanitation usually works best.
Evidence is mixed. Physical exclusion, traps, and targeted baiting are more dependable.
Often yes. Ask management about trash areas, basements, and exterior sealing.

name: Mold Remediation
metaTemplate: Local mold remediation for {area}... get quotes, tips, and a quick checklist.
checklist: Identify and fix the moisture source first
Ask about containment and air filtration
Request a written scope of work
Consider post-remediation testing if sensitive

faqs.a: Small surface issues may be manageable, but recurring mold usually indicates a moisture source that must be fixed.
Testing can help document conditions, especially for disputes or health concerns, but remediation should focus on moisture.
Small jobs can be a day; larger issues take longer depending on drying and repairs.

name: Air Quality Testing
metaTemplate: Local air quality testing for {area}... get quotes, tips, and a quick checklist.
checklist: Describe symptoms and timing (night, after rain, etc.)
Ask what the test measures and what it doesn’t
Review ventilation and humidity readings
Request clear next-step recommendations

faqs.q: What does air quality testing measure?
faqs.a: Depending on the provider, it may measure particulates, humidity, CO2, VOCs, and allergens. Confirm scope.

faqs.q: Will this prove a landlord issue?
faqs.a: It can document conditions, but results require interpretation. Pair with photos of leaks/vents when relevant.

faqs.q: How can I improve air quickly?
faqs.a: Ventilate, control humidity, use HEPA filtration, and address sources like leaks or pests.

name: Tenant Lawyers & Housing Court Help
titleTemplate: Tenant Lawyers in {area} (NYC) | Housing Court Help
metaTemplate: Find tenant lawyers serving {area}. Guidance for repairs, rent stabilization, harassment, and housing court.
checklist: Write down dates, photos, and copies of messages
Keep a timeline of issues and responses
Bring lease, riders, and notices
Ask about strategy and likely timeline

faqs.q: Can a lawyer help with repairs?
faqs.a: Yes—counsel can guide documentation, letters, and court/agency options depending on facts.

faqs.q: How do I know if I’m rent stabilized?
faqs.a: Some buildings are registered; a lawyer can advise. Keep paperwork and check your building history.

faqs.q: What should I bring to a consult?
faqs.a: Lease, notices, photos, repair requests, and a timeline. The clearer your record, the better advice you’ll get.

name: Home Inspection (Condo / Co-op)
metaTemplate: Book a condo/co-op home inspection for {area}. Learn what to check, typical issues, and how to use the report.
checklist: Confirm inspector experience with co-ops/condos
Ask about moisture, electrical, and HVAC checks
Request a clear report with photos
Use findings to plan repairs or negotiate

faqs.a: Yes. Even newer units can have moisture, electrical, or appliance issues. An inspection reduces surprises.

faqs.q: Will you inspect building common areas?
faqs.a: Typically you inspect the unit; some inspectors can note visible common-area concerns. Ask what’s included.
Many inspections take 2–4 hours depending on size and scope.

name: Internet & Wi-Fi Setup
metaTemplate: Internet and Wi‑Fi setup for {area}: provider availability, installation tips, and a quick router checklist.
checklist: Ask your building/doorman which providers serve the address
Confirm installation requirements and appointment windows
Choose router/mesh based on layout and walls
Test placement and update firmware

faqs.q: Which internet provider is best in {area}?
faqs.a: It depends on your specific building. Ask neighbors/doormen and compare availability, reliability, and install times.

faqs.q: Do I need a mesh system?
faqs.a: If you have thick walls or multiple rooms, mesh can improve coverage. Small apartments may do fine with one router.

faqs.q: How can I speed up installation?
faqs.a: Book early, confirm building access rules, and have your modem/router ready. Ask about self-install kits when possible.
